awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Single-Pulse Radio Frequency Software Suite to Improve Advanced Driver Assistance Systems Safety
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader/commercial impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is focused on developing software to enhance the performance of existing radar hardware on Advanced Driver Assistance Systems (ADAS). Despite development of ADAS sensing technologies, there are, on average, 14,386 car accidents per day in the United States alone. The performance of these technologies still needs to be improved significantly to ensure the safety of drivers. This project will transform the performance of current ADAS systems, reducing the number of car crashes and fatalities that occur daily. The total addressable market size for ADAS radar is estimated to be $6.61 billion, and this is the fastest growing market among all ADAS sensors. The current radar technology improvements being introduced today are focused on hardware, machine learning, and artificial intelligence. These current technologies are addressing issues that deal with resolution, but they come with the negative effects of slower processing times, higher cost, and less efficiency. The successful development of the software solutions in this project will disrupt the ADAS industry as this innovation is physics-based and can unlock the true potential of radar performance.

The intellectual merit of this project is focused on developing and deploying a software suite for remote sensing and data transmission using existing hardware. The software suite involves three primary steps: locating objects, identifying objects, and communicating the findings to other vehicles and/or infrastructure in the surrounding environment. The first two steps fall underneath the remote sensing category. The third falls under the communications category. Simulation development will be done for all three steps. Once robust simulations have been developed, the remote sensing portion of the software suite will be tested on an industry standard radar unit. The anticipated outcome of the test deployment is that the remote sensing piece of the software suite will enable conventional ADAS radars to achieve higher resolution and lower latency. This deployment is the first step in hardware development to create a safer and complete ADAS software suite. The results will be used to assess the reliability and feasibility of the proposed software suite in a real-world environment. Additionally, the results will be used to evaluate the efficacy of the software suite by benchmarking performance against current ADAS radar performance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The SoloPulse project aimed to enhance radar technology for advanced driver-assistance systems (ADAS). SoloPulse’s primary goal was to develop a software defined high-resolution radar imaging solution that could be easily integrated into existing ADAS platforms to improve safety and performance. One of our major achievements was creating a software solution that can work with radar data from any radar system (regardless of brand or system configuration) at various stages of processing, making it adaptable to different ADAS systems used by various customers. 

We successfully demonstrated that our technology (SoloSense) could accurately detect the position of objects, even in complex real-world scenarios. This capability is essential for reliable object detection and tracking, which is crucial for the safety and effectiveness of ADAS. We also proved that SoloSense could distinguish between closely spaced objects, a feature that enhances vehicle safety by providing better situational awareness. 

Another significant milestone achieved by SoloPulse was demonstrating the effectiveness of SoloSense in challenging urban environments. Cities often present complex challenges for radar systems due to factors like signal reflections from buildings and high levels of noise. Our project showed that SoloSense could overcome these issues, maintaining accurate object detections and tracks in densely populated areas, which is vital for the reliability of ADAS in urban settings. 

We achieved consistent performance across multiple radar frames, proving that SoloSense can reliably process continuous data streams with low latency. This is crucial for real-time applications, where continuous and accurate data processing is required to maintain safety and performance. We also demonstrated high-resolution 3D radar imaging outputs on conventional ADAS hardware (roughly 10% of the price of an imaging radar system), which offers more sophisticated capabilities for lower cost ADAS systems. 

The outcomes of the SoloPulse project have significant implications for ADAS technology. By providing a software defined high-resolution imaging radar with adaptable data processing, SoloSense enhances the accuracy and reliability of object detection and tracking. These improvements are critical for developing safer and more effective ADAS solutions, especially in challenging environments like urban areas. Additionally, reducing system costs makes advanced radar technology more accessible, potentially leading to broader adoption and improved road safety. 

Our advancements contribute to enhanced public safety by improving ADAS capabilities. More accurate and reliable radar systems can significantly reduce the likelihood of accidents, particularly in adverse weather conditions or complex urban environments. By making high-performance radar technology more accessible, SoloSense ensures that a wider range of vehicles and drivers can benefit from these safety innovations. 

The successful completion of Phase I provides a strong foundation for future work. We will continue to focus on scaling the technology for broader applications, conducting extensive real-world testing, and pursuing commercialization opportunities. The project team is also exploring potential collaborations and follow-on phases to build on the successes achieved thus far. 

In conclusion, the SoloPulse project has made significant strides in advancing radar technology for ADAS, achieving key milestones and demonstrating the potential for widespread impact on vehicle safety and performance. The flexibility, accuracy, and scalability of SoloSense makes it a transformative solution in the field of automotive radar systems.
